description:
Earth’s changing climate has caused an increase in hurricane risks and impacts. Warmer sea surface and atmospheric temperatures have resulted in more powerful hurricanes with stronger winds, more rain, and higher storm surges. In this module, students explore key variables that influence the risk of Atlantic hurricanes, investigate how the expected increase in hurricane strength threatens populations living along the coast, and consider the impacts that hurricanes have on these communities.

Finally, students address the guiding question: How will hurricane risks and impacts change over the next 100 years?
title: Cypress_Automated_Hurricane_Module

activities.description: In this introductory activity, you will explore the regions of the United States and the Carribean that are at risk of being impacted by an Atlantic hurricane. You will examine case studies and hurricane prediction maps and consider the locations where hurricanes are likely to strike and who is most at risk when they make landfall.

embeddables.content:
How will hurricane risks and impacts change over the next 100 years? This module will help you answer this question by giving you the chance to discover more about how hurricanes move and grow, who is at risk when a hurricane strikes, what natural hazards hurricanes bring, and how these hazards impact people and their communities. 

While hurricane scientists have improved in their knowledge and forecasts of hurricanes throughout the years, they still cannot know everything exactly. This module will help you understand what scientists know, what scientists cannot know, and why they cannot know these things. 

Watch this video about Hurricane Katrina, which hit Louisiana in August 2005, and then answer the questions below.

plugin.author_data:
{"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"framing","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"**Welcome to the Hurricane Module Teacher Edition! You can open and close this tip, and other teacher tips in this module, by clicking on the yellow Theory & Background button above.**

From severe flooding to sustained winds of hurricanes and unstoppable wildfires, natural disasters around the globe have caused devastation and had a major impact on millions of people’s lives. Unfortunately, we can’t prevent them from happening or predict them with 100 percent certainty. But it is important to learn about them if we are to make our society more resilient, especially in the face of climate change.
 
It is the goal of this module to teach the underlying core science related to what turns natural phenomenons into hazards. In addition, we want to help students consider the potential risks of hazards, which involves judging the likely occurrence of an event and the likely damage caused by the event. In line with the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS), this module engages students in the use of data gathered from explorations with the Hurricane Explorer, a model we developed to investigate variables that influence the track and intensity of hurricanes and the impacts to communities and environments in its path.
 
The goal of this first activity is to introduce students to hurricane forecasts. By starting with forecasts students consider what  makes a hurricane a hazard, who might be at risk from a specific hurricane, and why accurate forecasts are important even though they will always include some uncertainty. Students will accomplish this goal by exploring case-studies of hurricanes while beginning to consider how hurricanes impact humans and the environment. 

Student work throughout the module is driven by the guiding question: **How will hurricane risks and impacts change over the next 100 years?**","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. embeddables.content:
Hurricanes are so big that they can be seen from space! The picture below shows a satellite view of a storm named Hurricane Florence as it approached the United States in September of 2018. Notice the spot in the middle of the hurricane; that’s the eye of the storm. The strongest winds are around the eye.

When this photo was taken, the storm was still in the Atlantic Ocean, but scientists were still able to predict that it would hit land. Forecasting a storm to predict which places are most at risk is an important part of a meteorologist’s job. Scientists use many tools to monitor hurricanes as they form, grow, and move.

Forecasting both how intense a hurricane will be and where it is likely to make landfall can help people and communities prepare for the hazards that hurricanes bring. In this case, risk is the likelihood of loss, damage, or injury to people from a hurricane.

As the hurricane gets closer to making landfall, the predictions can be better, just like the one-day forecast for weather is better than the five-day weather forecast.","teacherTip":"Remember, this module has been designed to use research-based practices in science education, particularly Ambitious Science Teaching. Questions on this page may appear to ask students about things with which they are unfamiliar or have had no prior experience as part of a science class. It is okay if student explanations are incomplete or incorrect. The goal is to get a foundation on which students can build their ideas.","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

However, it is true that scientists cannot predict exactly where a hurricane will make landfall.  Although forecasting models have gotten better, exact predictions are still impossible.","distractorsExplanation":"Scientists can predict ranges of areas where a hurricane may make landfall, but these forecasts are for ranges of areas, not the particular area where a storm's eye will make landfall. 

Forecasting models have gotten better, but they are not perfect predictors of storm movements.","exemplar":"","teacherTip":"Scientists understand how hurricanes form, how they grow, and how they usually move across the Atlantic Ocean. During the hurricane season, they use multiple tools, such as satellites and radar, to monitor hurricanes. Several powerful computer models have also been developed in the last few decades to help predict hurricane paths. These models take multiple variables into consideration and use data from past hurricanes to help predict future hurricanes. 

All that said, scientists still cannot predict exactly where a hurricane will hit! Scientists are most accurate with their predictions the closer a hurricane is to shore.
","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

plugin.author_data:
{"tipType":"questionWrapper","questionWrapper":{"correctExplanation":"","distractorsExplanation":"","exemplar":"For one thing, hurricanes are huge. A storm doesn't have to make a direct hit to land to affect the land. Heavy rain and strong winds can happen on the outer bands of a storm. 

For another thing, risks to humans don't stop at the water's edge. Fishermen can be affected even if a storm doesn't make landfall or even come really near the land. The storm's winds push the water into waves that can damage boats and put lives in jeopardy. 

The storm can produce rip currents that pose a danger to swimmers as well. These effects can happen even while a storm is far off-shore.","teacherTip":"Students' answers will vary. What is important is that they are thinking about risk in terms of risk to people and their communities. Some students may point out that a hurricane that doesn't make landfall, but moves close to land, still poses a risk to people living close to the shore. This is definitely true.  A hurricane that passes close to the coast can bring devastating hazards.

Students may have other ideas as well. Some students may point out that if a hurricane passes near a deserted island, the island ecosystem--including the plants and animals living there--may be affected. Students may also point of out that hurricanes are a risk for people who are out on boats in the ocean.","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

embeddables.content:
A hazard is something that will produce damages and losses such as strong winds, precipitation, and storm surge. A hurricane becomes a natural hazard when it approaches or passes over a region where people live or work.

A group called NOAA (National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration) tracks hurricanes and keeps people informed when a hurricane is likely to make landfall in the United States or Carribean. Weather reporters rely on public advisories like this one to inform the public of coming storms. The following public advisory from NOAA was posted at 11:00 PM on Monday, September 10, 2018 for the Southeastern United States. At that time, Tropical Storm Florence had formed in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean.

Read the public advisory and answer the questions below.

{"version":1,"url":"http://has-production.s3.amazonaws.com/resources/geohazard-hurricane/florence%20advisory_highlighted.jpg","caption":"","credit":"NOAA (National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration)","creditLink":"","creditLinkDisplayText":"","allowLightbox":true,"scaling":"fitWidth"}

embeddables.content:
A hurricane becomes a natural hazard when it comes close to people. This includes anywhere that people live and work such as those on boats, on the coast, or inland. There are a lot of hurricanes that form and never pose a risk to people. However, when storms start moving close to the United States and Caribbean, scientists take notice! 

How do scientists predict if, when, and where a hurricane will hit? 

Scientists use models built on large data sets from past hurricanes to predict future hurricane paths (tracks) and intensity. However, scientists can not be perfect in their predictions because hurricanes are complex. To represent where the hurricane might travel, scientists use a cone of uncertainty, which shows the likely location of a hurricane in the near future.

The cone of uncertainty for Hurricane Florence is shown as the white shaded area in the slide show below. The size, shape, and location of the cone of uncertainty is based off the historical tracks of hurricanes from the past five years. 

Click through the slideshow and watch how the cone of uncertainty's shape and area change as Hurricane Florence moves along its path. Use your observations to answer the questions below.

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"questionWrapper","questionWrapper":{"correctExplanation":"","distractorsExplanation":"","exemplar":"The near-term future diameter is always smaller than the longer-term future diameter. \n\nThe storm appears to be more difficult to track once it makes landfall. All of the graphics that show landfall predictions have much wider diameters on land than are present while the storm is over the ocean.","teacherTip":"Students should notice that the cone is wider the farther out the forecast is. While scientists are more certain about projecting a hurricane's path 1 to 3 days out, there is more uncertainty in forecasts extending 4 or more days in the future.","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"theoryAndBackground","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"Major hazards associated with hurricanes include: * Storm surge—an abnormal rise of water generated by a storm’s winds. * Heavy rainfall and flooding—storms often produce and excess of 6 inches of rain in a short period of time that can result in excessive flooding. * High winds—hurricane force winds over 74 mph. * Rip currents and tornadoes. Because the hazards are so great, meteorologists forecast the path of hurricanes in an attempt to inform those in possible danger from impacts of the hazard. Once a hurricane has formed, scientists predict its path and generate forecasts using different computer models and by varying conditions in the models. The various forecast models create predictions of a hurricane’s path and intensity. Each will predict slightly different tracks. The cone of uncertainty is a representation of the probable track of the center of a hurricane based on the computer models. Included in the cone is representation of the uncertainty in the forecast. The cone of uncertainty is a frequently misunderstood representation. It is important to help your students understand what it represents. For a very clear description on how to interpret the cone of uncertainty, see the interactive infographic published by the New York Times: Those Hurricane Maps Don’t Mean What You Think They Mean ","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. embeddables.content:
The cone shows where the eye of the storm will track. But, hurricanes can be several hundred miles across. Even though the strongest winds are near the center of a hurricane, strong winds, heavy rain, lightning storms, and tornadoes are likely to occur in the entire area that the storm covers.

Look carefully at the image to the right. It shows the cone of uncertainy for Hurricane Florence on September 12 at 8am and an actual satellite photograph of the hurricane.

embeddables.content:
Scientists have improved their models over the past few years, which has made predicting hurricane tracks more accurate. Look at the graphic below. It shows where the cone of uncertainty would have been drawn for a hurricane located in the same spot, if it were drawn in 4 different years.

In 2004, the width of the cone was wider, which means there was less accuracy in the forecasts. Over time, the cone has changed in size. In 2019, the cone is much narrower, meaning there is more accuracy about the potential track of the hurricane.

embeddables.authored_state: {"version":1,"url":"https://has-production.s3.amazonaws.com/resources/geohazard-hurricane/2019_04_conecomparison.png","caption":"Hurricane track forecasts have improved over time. A wider cone means there is more uncertainty in the prediction.","credit":"Brian McNoldy, University of Miami's Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science","creditLink":"https://bmcnoldy.blogspot.com/2019/05/cone-of-uncertainty-update-and-refresher.html","creditLinkDisplayText":"","allowLightbox":true,"scaling":"fitWidth"}

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"teacherTip","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"In order to elicit students’ ideas and track them through the module, we suggest you use an off-line tool called a Summary Table. Summary Tables can be used individually by students to record their thinking as they progress toward an explanatory model of the phenomenon and guiding question: **How will hurricane risks and impacts change over the next 100 years?** A Summary Table can also be used to record students' ideas in a public place, such as a poster or a projected online document shared at the front of the room. (Please read these brief instructions on how to use Summary Tables.) Throughout this Teacher Edition of the module, we will highlight those places where we suggest you **stop, gather student ideas, and record them on the Summary Table.** This is a good place to stop, introduce, and populate the first row of the summary table. Incorporating a background of risk and how the cone of uncertainty informs decision making can provide support for the explanations the students develop at the end of the module. embeddables.content:
Once a hurricane moves closer to land, it is easier to predict where it will hit. Once a hurricane is likely to make landfall, people and their communities must plan for the hazards that the hurricane may bring.

More than 1 million people on the Southeast Coast of the United States faced mandatory evacuation orders as Hurricane Florence neared Category 5 strength. Despite the official order, many people remained in the high risk areas.

embeddables.authored_state: {"version":1,"url":"https://has-production.s3.amazonaws.com/resources/geohazard-hurricane/CarsEvacuating.jpg","caption":"Following mandatory evacuation orders, hundreds of thousands of people leave their homes to wait out the hurricane in a safer location.\r\nFEMA","credit":"","creditLink":"","creditLinkDisplayText":"","allowLightbox":true,"scaling":"fitWidth"}

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"discussionPoints","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"*This is a great place to stop and elicit students’ initial ideas about the hazards and risks of hurricanes.* This page introduces the socio-economic issues that arise when communities prepare for hurricanes and other natural disasters. This topic will be visited again later in the module. However, because of the complexity of this issue the module will only address a few of these issues. At this point, eliciting students’ initial ideas about risks to different populations is important. Both preparing for hurricanes (buying supplies and staying put) and evacuating (access to reliable transportation and having a safe place to go) can be expensive. Asking questions like, “Why is it more difficult for older people or sick people to prepare for a hurricane?” and "Why is it more difficult for people from low socioeconomic communities to evacuate during a hurricane?" will generate rich class discussions. We suggest you use an off-line tool called a Summary Table to record student ideas. Summary Tables can be used individually by students to track their thinking as they progress toward an explanatory model of the phenomenon and guiding question: **How will hurricane risks and impacts change over the next 100 years? ** A Summary Table can also be used to record student ideas in a public place, such as a poster or a projected online document shared at the front of the room. (Please read these brief instructions on how to use Summary Tables.)","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. Gallery [OR] Location. http://www.url.com.","mediaURL":""}}

activities.description: In this activity, you will use the Hurricane Explorer to investigate the factors that influence hurricane strength. You will explore seasonal effects on hurricane formation, growth, and movement. You will also begin to draw parallels between rising trends in sea surface temperature and the frequency of high intensity hurricanes.

embeddables.content:
In the last activity, you explored how high and low air pressure systems affect a hurricane's path. In this activity, you will use Hurricane Explorer to investigate the factors that influence the intensity of hurricanes. Hurricanes are classified into five divisions based on their wind speeds. The classification scale is called the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale.

Hurricane Katrina was the third largest storm ever to hit the United States, with winds of 140 mph extending 100 miles from the center. Why was this storm so intense? What factors increase or decrease a hurricane's intensity? In this activity, you will explore what causes storms to become more intense.

The graphic below shows how wind speeds determine hurricane categories and the impacts associated with wind strength.

Maximum sustained wind speeds of 96-110 mph are associated with Category 2 hurricanes.

Maximum sustained wind speeds of 111-129 mph are associated with Category 3 hurricanes.

Maximum sustained wind speeds of 130-156 mph are associated with Category 4 hurricanes.","exemplar":"","teacherTip":"","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

embeddables.content:
You have seen that tropical storms in the Atlantic often form off the coast of Africa. Tropical storms get their name because they form over tropical oceans, where warm water and winds interact and can produce large storms. As a tropical storm intensifies and the winds get stronger, it reaches hurricane classification.

Use the Hurricane Explorer below to investigate how the temperature of the water at the surface of the ocean, called the sea surface temperature (SST), affects hurricanes as they travel. How does sea surface temperature affect hurricane strength? (It is important to remember that Earth systems are complicated and the Hurricane Explorer model does not include every factor.)

In addition, the key to the SST colors is shown when the tab is open.\n","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"top"}}

plugin.author_data:
{"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"theoryAndBackground","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 to November 30 as hurricanes form over the ocean. Due to our warming climate, the number of Category 4 and 5 hurricanes each year is trending up. With a warmer atmosphere comes increased ocean temperatures. **High sea surface temperatures are directly correlated with increased hurricane intensity because storms gain strength as they move over warm water.** And as sea levels rise, so does the potential height of storm surges. While high winds can cause serious damage, storm surge is the most dangerous impact of hurricanes, inundating entire communities and causing flooding well inland.

As the temperature of Earth’s atmosphere climbs, the sea surface temperature rises. It is easy to see how climate change, and rising temperatures, have the potential for directly affecting the intensity of hurricanes. Climate change is also responsible for sea level rise; as glacial ice melts, the sea level rises. **As the sea levels rise, the level of storm surges and the damage that goes along with it, will also increase.** Scientists are still unsure if the total number of hurricanes per season will increase with climate change. Signs point in that direction but lack of reliable hurricane records provide a degree of uncertainty.

The goal of this activity is to have students use Hurricane Explorer to investigate the role of seasonal changes on hurricane formation and the effect of sea surface temperature on hurricane intensity. Students will use the Hurricane Explorer to investigate how these factors influence hurricane formation, growth and, ultimately, dissipation.

At the end of this activity, students will understand the factors in a hurricane system that affect its path and strength including the location and magnitude of pressure systems, seasons (winter, spring, summer and fall), sea surface temperature, and location of landfall.","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. Gallery [OR] Location. http://www.url.com.","mediaURL":""}}

In order to investigate sea surface temperature in the model, click the Maps Overlays tab and then click Sea Surface Temperature.

Click the orange "season" button, at the bottom of the model, to change seasons from winter to spring to summer to fall. Notice the change in sea surface temperature. 

Run the model in each season and see what happens!

embeddables.content:
Hurricane Explorer includes maps of the average sea surface temperature in each season (winter, spring, summer, and fall). Use the model to examine which seasons are more or less likely to produce hurricanes that reach the east coast of North America.

Which seasons are more likely to have strong hurricanes?

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"questionWrapper","questionWrapper":{"correctExplanation":"A storm that starts in the spring will generally stay a tropical storm. The tropical storm does not last as long as it does in other seasons because the water temperature is not warm enough to support storm development.","distractorsExplanation":"A storm that starts in the spring will not strengthen faster than a storm that forms in other seasons. The water temperature is not warm enough to support storm growth.\n\nBecause of the cooler water temperatures, storms that form in the spring behave differently than storms that form in other seasons, when the water surface temperatures are higher.","exemplar":"","teacherTip":"If students are having trouble answering this question, they may not realize that they can change the seasons. At the bottom of the model, click the orange Season button to toggle through winter, spring, summer, and fall.","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"questionWrapper","questionWrapper":{"correctExplanation":"","distractorsExplanation":"","exemplar":"The sea surface temperature is cool throughout the spring. It has cooled all winter and needs to rewarm during the spring and summer months. The water is only warm enough to support storms in the summer (earlier summer for lower latitudes; later summer for upper latitudes). After the summer, the water is really warmed up, so the fall is supportive of storm growth. But after the fall, the water starts to cool again so that the winter months are not conducive to storm growth. This means July through October could support the most hurricanes.","teacherTip":"Students might wonder why hurricanes happen in the fall, right as the temperature in the northern hemisphere is getting cooler.  \n\nWater has a high heat capacity, and the oceans are large bodies of water.  Because of this, there is a delay in cooling. Even though the air temperature is dropping, the ocean remains warm for a few months into the fall season.","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

pages.name: Rising sea surface temperature and hurricane intensity

embeddables.content:
You have seen in Hurricane Explorer that when hurricanes move over warmer areas of the ocean, they are more likely to increase intensity and turn into a higher category storm.

You may now be wondering how and why warmer sea surface temperatures are likely to result in more major hurricanes (category 3 and higher). Watch this video about how hurricanes form and grow. Then, answer the questions below.

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"questionWrapper","questionWrapper":{"correctExplanation":"","distractorsExplanation":"","exemplar":"A hurricane needs warm water, moist air, and converging winds in order to form. To strengthen, it needs continued moist air and warm water.","teacherTip":"","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

They continue to die out as long as there is no energy source to refuel them.","teacherTip":"","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

plugin.author_data:
{"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"theoryAndBackground","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"**Will the frequency and intensity of hurricanes change over time?**
 
As the temperature of Earth’s atmosphere climbs, the sea surface temperature rises. High sea surface temperatures are directly correlated with increased hurricane intensity because storms gain strength as they move over warm water.
 
The warmer the water temperature, the more heat energy is available, and the higher the likelihood that hurricane intensity will increase.  
 
In terms of frequency, there is no discernible trend in the number of hurricanes. Scientists are not sure about what the future will bring.
 
Hurricane systems are complex but it is expected that stronger winds, more rain and worsened storm surges will result from climate change which means there is more potential for destruction.  
","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. Gallery [OR] Location. http://www.url.com.","mediaURL":""}}

embeddables.content:
One of the jobs of hurricane scientists is to make long term forecasts of the number of hurricanes that will form in the next hurricane season. To do this, scientists study historical data and climate conditions.

On the graph below, each line is colored according to the number of tropical storms, hurricanes, and major hurricanes that formed in that year. The data includes all the Atlantic Ocean storms for every fifth year from 1860-2015. A major hurricane is one that reaches a Category 3 or higher.

embeddables.content:
Now, examine the graph below. 

This graph shows temperature anomalies. An anomaly is the difference in temperature from the average. The average temperature used in this graph is calculated from the temperatures between 1951 and 1980. Blue bars represent years that were colder than average. Red bars represent years that were warmer than average.

activities.description: You will experiment with the Hurricane Explorer model, which allows you to adjust environmental factors related to hurricane movement such as the location and magnitude of high and low pressure systems. After you develop an understanding of how high and low pressure drive the motion of hurricanes, you will use your knowledge to investigate the tracts of real-world hurricanes.

embeddables.content:
Watch the video below as several storms move from east to west across the Atlantic Ocean in 2011.

This video was taken during the height of hurricane season. In this activity, you will explore some of the factors that cause hurricanes to move across the Atlantic Ocean. While many storms start in about the same area off of west coast of Africa, they don’t all make landfall in North America. What do you think changes the track of storms? 

It is important to understand how storms move in order to predict if and where a storm will make landfall!

embeddables.content:
Scientists categorize hurricanes into five groups based on their wind speeds. The stronger the winds, the higher the category of the hurricane. Category 4 and 5 hurricanes are the strongest hurricanes.

The map below shows all of the category 4 and 5 hurricanes in the Atlantic Ocean since 1851. Each line on the graphic below represents the track of the eye for one storm. There have been alot of storms!

embeddables.content:
One of the main factors that affects the path of hurricanes is the location of atmospheric pressure systems.

There are two types of pressure systems that occur in the atmosphere, high pressure systems and low pressure systems. In general, air flows from regions of high pressure to low pressure. The flow of air between and around pressure systems push hurrianes along their path. Meteorologists often map the location of pressure systems to predict where hurricanes will move.

Look at the diagram below. On the left, you can see a low pressure system, where air is drawn in towards the center. A high pressure system is shown on the right. High pressure systems push air away from their center. You will notice that the arrows representing air flow are curved, this is because air at the surface is affected by the spin of the earth!

plugin.author_data:
{"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"theoryAndBackground","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"If you have not covered high and low pressure systems prior to this module this would be a good time to stop students and make sure they understand the following:

* In a **low pressure system**, air warms and moves upwards leading to low pressure at the center.
* Winds blow towards the low pressure and the air rises in the atmosphere where the winds meet.
* A **high pressure system** has higher pressure at its center than the areas around it.  Cooler air from higher in the atmosphere sinks towards the surface of Earth.
* Wind blows away from high pressure.
* Air will always move from high pressure to low pressure.

In the model, students should observe that as a hurricane moves the winds from a high pressure system steer the hurricane away from the center of the pressure system. In contrast, if a hurricane moves near a low pressure system, the hurricane will move towards the pressure system. 

During tropical storm formation, the pressure in the center of the storm drops resulting in a greater pressure difference between the storm and the air outside the storm. The greater the pressure difference, the stronger the winds! For more information on the basics of pressure systems, take a look at this page from the UCAR Center for Science Education:
https://scied.ucar.edu/learning-zone/how-weather-works/highs-and-lows-air-pressure","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. Gallery [OR] Location. http://www.url.com.","mediaURL":""}}

Hurricane Explorer is a simulation that shows hurricane behavior based on a variety of adjustable variables. It allows you to watch the path of a hurricane as it travels across the Atlantic Ocean. It is important to remember that Earth systems are complicated and the Hurricane Explorer model does not include every factor.


Click the "Start" button to run the model. Watch how the hurricane moves. See if and where the hurricane makes landfall. Use the model to answer the questions below.

embeddables.content:
Hurricane Irene was a tropical storm that grew into a major hurricane in August 2011. The maximum sustained wind speeds reached 120 mph as the storm traveled over the Caribbean and towards the east coast of the United States. 

In Activity 1, you learned about Hurricane Katrina, which hit the Gulf Coast of the United States in August 2005. 

A number of factors determine the track of a storm. As hurricanes move and change direction they also change in intensity. Below are the paths of both Hurricane Irene and Hurricane Katrina.

Below is a graphic of the path of Hurricane Florence as it was tracked by satellites orbiting the Earth. Use what you learned in this activity to recreate the path of Hurricane Florence by correctly placing the location of the pressure systems in the Hurricane Explorer.

project.title: GeoHazard

embeddables.content:
You now know how hurricanes move and grow and how scientists predict if and when they might make landfall. In this activity, you will investigate the natural hazards that hurricanes bring when they make landfall: high winds, heavy rains, and storm surge.

According to the United States Census Bureau, coastline communities were home to an estimated 94 million people in 2016. That is 29% of the total population! These areas continue to experience population growth. It is important to consider what it means for this growing number of people who live in the path of potentially destructive storms.

plugin.author_data:
{"tipType":"questionWrapper","questionWrapper":{"correctExplanation":"People may not evacuate even as a hurricane approaches because they have jobs that they need to attend to. These jobs could be public safety jobs, such as EMTs, fire, police, or medical staff, that are especially required after a natural disaster. 

People may not evacuate because their families are in the area. Some family members may be unable to move due to illness, and their loved ones do not want them to be left alone.

People may not evacuate because they want to experience the winds and waves that a hurricane produces. Some people may want to surf the waves or create videos of the storm to post online.

People may not want to evacuate because they attend school in the area. People may move to an area to attend school and not want to move away from that opportunity even with the added risk of hurricanes.","distractorsExplanation":"","exemplar":"","teacherTip":"","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

embeddables.content:
As you can see from this photograph, taken in 2017, of Puerto Rico days after Hurricane Maria, winds can cause tremendous destruction. Sometimes tornadoes can occur during hurricanes! 

The strongest winds occur close to the center, or eye, of a hurricane. The center of Hurricane Maria went directly over the island of Puerto Rico, which is why the island experienced such devastating wind damage.

Look at the photo below to investigate what the wind speeds were when Hurricane Maria hit Puerto Rico.

plugin.author_data:
{"tipType":"questionWrapper","questionWrapper":{"correctExplanation":"","distractorsExplanation":"","exemplar":"","teacherTip":"You may want to project this page and work through the questions as a class. The chart included on this page lists hazards that some students may not be aware of. Explore these ideas further with students.

For example, strong winds can knock down power lines. One or two downed power lines are easily repaired in a few days. **With more intense storms with stronger winds, more damage results, so the time needed to clean up, repair, and rebuild is extended.** 

Electricity may be out for days, weeks, or months. Roads may be closed for days, weeks, or months after the storm has passed. Hurricane Maria left 60,000 people without power, and it took 11 months for power to be restored.

","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"top"}}

* What if your grandparents couldn’t go to the doctor? 
* What if your school was destroyed and needed to be rebuilt?

And:

* What are some ways that wind damage can affect animals and their habitats?

embeddables.content:
Just like wind, rain is intense at the center of a hurricane. However, since hurricanes can be hundreds of miles wide and move slowly, they can bring several days of rain and thunderstorms! Hurricane Maria covered Puerto Rico in over 38 inches of rain in less than 2 days. The rain from Hurricane Maria impacted the people in Puerto Rico in many ways.

Water damage to houses can be severe. Often times houses that are damaged from flooding cannot be repaired and need to be entirely rebuilt. Roads in Puerto Rico were closed not only because of downed trees but also because pavement that had been washed away. The Puerto Rican people worked together for months to restore power, clean up debris, regain access to fresh water, and rebuild roads and houses.

It was destroyed by a mudslide, caused by flooding.\u003C/p\u003E\r\n\u003Cp\u003EWhat are some other ways that heavy rainfall could impact people and their communities who aren't on the coastline?\u003C/p\u003E","defaultAnswer":"","required":false,"questionType":"open_response","predictionFeedback":false,"hint":""}

{"tipType":"questionWrapper","questionWrapper":{"correctExplanation":"","distractorsExplanation":"","exemplar":"Answers will vary.

Heavy rainfall could result in flooding. If a community is located near a river or in a low-lying area, the excessive rain could result in severe local and/or widespread flooding.

Students might say that flooding can ruin houses, schools, and stores. People may have to wait a long time for their house to be rebuilt or their school to open again.","teacherTip":"Encourage group discussion about other ways that floods can impact people and their communities. Water can carry materials to places that they shouldn't be. Fast-moving water can carry large objects, such as boats and houses, away from their starting locations. As the debris moves in the water, it can cause more destruction.

Farm waste and sewage can be spread and enter the water supply. Dangerous chemicals from factories, farms, and people's garages can also be spread this way. ","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

embeddables.content:
Earlier, you learned that the Saffir-Simpson Wind Scale is used to classify hurricanes is based on the storm's sustained wind speed. Unlike wind speed, there is no rain scale that relates the amount of rain with the category of hurricane.

Slow moving Category 1 and 2 storms can bring just as much rain as Category 4 and 5 storms. The amount of rain a hurricane can drop depends on how long it spends over warm ocean waters. The more time a storm spends over warm ocean waters, the more water vapor can be added to the storm system.

pages.name: Storm Surge Impacts and Sea Level Rise

embeddables.content:
Storm surge is the deadliest hazard of hurricanes as a large amount of water quickly floods the land. Storm surge is produced by water being pushed toward the shore by the force of winds moving around the hurricane center. Salty sea water can move several miles inland if the winds are strong enough and the land is flat enough. Storm surge is very dangerous! If people haven't evacuated, they could drown in the rising waters.

Below is an animation of how storm surge forms and its effect on coastal cities.

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"questionWrapper","questionWrapper":{"correctExplanation":"","distractorsExplanation":"","exemplar":"Storm surge can travel up rivers that drain to the ocean and impact the people live there. Their properties could be flooded and possessions could be carried away by the currents.","teacherTip":"","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

plugin.author_data: {"tipType":"questionWrapper","questionWrapper":{"correctExplanation":"","distractorsExplanation":"","exemplar":"Rising sea levels would increase the risk of impacts of storm surge to coastal communities. People who live next to the sea today could be living in the sea if the sea level rises enough. This makes people who live farther from the sea now effectively living closer to the sea in the future. Even a little bit more storm surge could be a big deal if you're closer to the water (with more storm surge being worse). \n\nStorm surge does not only affect the areas near beaches. Storm surge also affects other waterways that connect to the ocean, such as rivers and estuaries. The storm surge moves far inland up rivers, where storm surge experienced several miles up a river can be just as bad as the storm surge experienced along a beach on the ocean.","teacherTip":"","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

plugin.author_data:
{"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"theoryAndBackground","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"**Storm surge is the most dangerous hazard that hurricanes can bring as it can result in drowning.** 

A storm surge is the result of many factors working in concert with one another resulting in a rise in water level. These factors include the low pressure in the middle of the storm “sucking” water up, the intense cyclonic winds pushing water, astronomical tides, and the slope of the continental shelf to name a few. Coastal communities can be severely damaged by a large storm surge. In addition to water moving further inland when the slope of the land is shallow, the extra high tides associated with the storm surge accelerate erosion of beaches and can potentially damage nearby structures. 

In low lying areas, storm surge can bring salty sea water miles inland through rivers. Students may know that the salt in sea water can quickly kill plants and crops. They may not know that salt is a powerful corrosive chemical that can ruin many man-made materials, damaging buildings, roads, and even electrical wires.
","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. Gallery [OR] Location. http://www.url.com.","mediaURL":""}}

embeddables.content:
Nature can be a powerful force, especially if you are in the path of a hurricane. How do hurricanes impact people and the environment?

You will use the Hurricane Explorer to see how all three hurricane hazards – wind, rain, and storm surge – impact the people and communities on a hurricane's path. Hurricane Explorer contains map tools to help you analyze each type of hazard and its potential impact. The questions below are just like the ones that meteorologists ask themselves when analyzing a hurricane's path.

Use the Hurricane Explorer to produce hurricanes that hit the United States. Create as many as you want, and when you are happy with one, use that hurricane to answer the questions below.

activities.description:
The future of hurricane risk is complex and is being actively researched by scientists. In this final activity, you will investigate how climate change correlates to projected changes in hurricane frequency, intensity, risk, and impact. You will model hurricane occurrence in a future that includes higher sea surface temperatures, higher sea levels, and more extensive human development in coastal communities. 

By the end of this activity, you should be better able to answer the guiding question: How will hurricane risks and impacts change over the next 100 years?
activities.name: Future Risk

project.title: GeoHazard

embeddables.content:
At the beginning of this module, you were asked to think about the question: How will hurricane risks and impacts change over the next 100 years? 

In this activity, you will consider how changes in atmospheric and oceanic temperatures might predict what hurricanes will be like in 100 years.

Global temperatures are warming and this change in climate is affecting many of the natural processes on Earth. The warming trend of both the air and oceans over the last century impacts everything from ocean currents to bird migrations. The patterns of hurricanes have changed as well. 

NOAA has measured an increase in average global sea surface temperature, as shown on the graph below. This graph shows how the average surface temperature of the world's oceans has changed since 1880. The graph shows the temperature anomaly for each year, which is the difference between the temperature measurement for each year and the baseline average temperature, which is shown by the horizontal dotted line. The shaded band shows the range of uncertainty in the data, based on the number of measurements collected and the precision of the methods used.

{"tipType":"questionWrapper","questionWrapper":{"correctExplanation":"","distractorsExplanation":"","exemplar":"I think that the sea surface temperature is likely to be warmer in the future rather than colder. How much the temperature will increase is dependent on many factors that are beyond my predictive ability. 

If they chose line A: If greenhouse gases continue to rise and the air temperature increases more, sea surface temperatures will increase more.

If they chose line B: If humans are able to limit and decrease their carbon dioxide emissions in the next few years, the ocean will stop increasing in temperature, but will stay at the temperature it is at currently.

If they chose line C:  SST will decrease if humans are able to significantly decrease the amount of greenhouse gas emissions in the immediate future. Without additional greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, the temperature may start decreasing back to its "natural" state  in 100 years. This is unlikely, however.","teacherTip":"","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

plugin.author_data:
{"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"framing","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"The goal of this final activity in the hurricane module is to have students consider the complexities of preparing for and recovering from major hurricanes. Until this point students have explored the factors that influence the track and intensity of hurricanes. **In this activity students will explore future risks and impacts from hurricanes.**

Students begin the activity by looking at real-world data showing changes in global atmospheric temperature and sea-level rise. Then, they will make predictions about how changes in sea surface temperature might affect how hurricanes might behave differently 100 years in the future. Finally, students will be asked to assess risks from hazards to specific populations and explore resiliency. 
This activity explores the complexity of hurricane predictions as they relate to changes in Earth’s climate. **What is most important in this activity is that students use evidence from the entire module to reason and that students include uncertainty which is a core aspect of predicting near term and long term outcomes.**
","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. Gallery [OR] Location. http://www.url.com.","mediaURL":""}}

embeddables.content: Below is a graph of measurements of sea level from 1880 to 2014. It was produced by NASA’s Earth Observatory lab by monitoring tide gauges around the world, and later supplemented with satellite images. Scitentists connect sea level rise with melting ice from land areas near the North and South Poles such as Greenland and Antarctica.

embeddables.content:
The ocean and atmosphere interact to create weather and climate patterns. In this module, you have observed those patterns with hurricanes. As you saw in your investigations, it is more difficult to get a storm to form over the ocean in the winter and spring because of lower sea surface temperatures.

On the previous page, you made a prediction for the trend of sea surface temperature in the future. How will that trend affect hurricanes?

Below is a model of a hypothetical Hurricane Concord. The storm starts off the coast of Africa, moves east to the Caribbean, and turns north along the east coast of the United States. Many different regions are impacted by this storm!

Observe the wind speeds, storm surge, and impacts of Hurricane Concord. Then, predict how thes eimpacts would change 100 years in the future.

Then the storm traveled through Jacksonville, which has tens of thousands of people. The storm exited to the ocean again near Virginia Beach, which has tens of thousands of people. 

It passed very near Atlantic City, NJ, which has tens of thousands of people, and New York, NY, which is populated with hundreds of thousands of people. That's not even mentioning all of the smaller areas that were affected by the direct path and the many more who were within the range of high winds and rainfall.

There was really heavy rain, especially in the Baltimore/Washington area, the Philadelphia area, and the Boston area. ","teacherTip":"","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

{"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"theoryAndBackground","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"**Vulnerability is defined as the characteristics of a person or group and their situation that influences their capacity to cope with and recover from the impact of a natural hazard.** 

It is important to remind your students that different populations face different levels of risk and vulnerability. Some of the most important factors that affect vulnerability include population growth and the distribution of populations located in areas that are in danger of hazards. Increasing numbers of people are choosing to live in areas that are at increasing risk for natural devastation. 
 
In addition, social and economic characteristics of a group may limit its members’ abilities to protect themselves from harm. Poverty is a primary factor that affects how individuals are able to deal with risk. People living in low income areas tend not to have less resources available to respond to or recover from disasters. Other factors that affect vulnerability include age and disability. While we do introduce the topic of vulnerability, we are not able to address these issues in depth with-in the module. We encourage you to engage students in classroom discussion to explore vulnerability, but you will need to decide how deeply you will go. Here are some additional resources if you choose to include more discussions.
","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. Gallery [OR] Location. http://www.url.com.","mediaURL":""}}

embeddables.content:
How can people living at or near the coast stay safe as the risk of hurricanes increases in the future?

Look at the NOAA Sea Level Rise Viewer images below. These images show an area around Charleston, South Carolina that is likely to be underwater during high tide as the sea level rises. If Earth's global temperature continues to rise at the current rate, sea levels will continue to rise. Scientists estimate that the average amount of sea level rise around the planet will be approximately 2 to 3 and a half feet.

embeddables.content:
More and more people are moving to the coasts. In fact, the population of people living on the coast of the United States grew by nearly 35 million people between 1970 and 2010. The trend does not appear to be slowing down.

Resiliency is defined as the ability to recover quickly from a disaster. There are steps communities can take to become more resilient, decrease their vulnerability to storms, lower the risk of hurricane hazards, and reduce the impacts associated with these disasters. 

Watch the video below to see how some cities are preparing for future hurricanes.

{"version":1,"url":"https://has-production.s3.amazonaws.com/resources/geohazard-hurricane/SatelliteCharlestonSC.png","caption":"Satellite view of Charleston, South Carolina and the surrounding area.","credit":"Edited from Google Maps","creditLink":"","creditLinkDisplayText":"","allowLightbox":true,"scaling":"fitWidth"}

embeddables.content:
Despite the enormous benefits wetlands provide, they cannot completely eliminate flooding hazards. It is inevitable that coastal cities and communities will flood due to hurricanes. Implementing and enforcing new building codes is another way to reduce flood damages and increase resiliency.

The picture below shows elevated houses in Outer Banks, North Carolina, which were designed to avoid flooding from intense storms.

","credit":"North Carolina Department of Transportation","creditLink":"","creditLinkDisplayText":"","allowLightbox":true,"scaling":"fitWidth"}

Some questions to seed the discussion on mitigation and resiliency are:
* Perhaps ask students to think about what should be a coastal town's plan for a future hurricane?
* What might a town do to reduce impact?
* What do they need to have in place to respond to events? 
* What environmental plans might they do?
* Will these things make a difference even as climate changes?

embeddables.content:
Hurricane forecasts are improving. Scientists are now able to more accurately predict the time and location a hurricane will impact certain communities. This is due to better hurricane models and more data points being used to compute the track. 

Advances in prediction can significantly help communities prepare for hurricanes. Knowing if a hurricane is likely to impact your town even six hours further in advance can help communities prepare for the storm. 

Communities have to prepare in different ways. A city on the coast prepares for hurricanes differently than a small agricultural town. Using what you have learned about the hazards that hurricanes bring, their impact, and mitigation techniques, make a preparation plan for one of the locations (A, B, or C) along the track of Hurricane Concord below.

plugin.author_data:
{"tipType":"questionWrapper","questionWrapper":{"correctExplanation":"","distractorsExplanation":"","exemplar":"**Sample answer for Choice A (Puerto Rico)**:

I think this location would be at more risk in the future. Sea surface temperature continues to rise around the island, meaning hurricanes will only be stronger as they pass by Puerto Rico. Additionally, Puerto Rico is right in the path of many hurricanes that start iff the coast of Africa, and if more hurricanes can form there is a greater chance that they will be hit. 

Any storm impact is a big impact on an island. Most of the people live along the coast, putting them at risk of storm surge, flooding, and intense winds. Heavy precipitation contributes to the flooding risk and can result in landslides on the mountainous island. 


**Sample answer for Choice B (Wilmington, NC)**:

Wilmington could be at higher risk of hurricanes in the future. As hurricanes become stringer, their strong winds can persist farther inland and create conditions never before seen in the town. 

As a smaller city near the coast, Wilmington can still be affected by a hurricane's intense winds, heavy precipitation, and flooding. Storm surge is a lesser concern unless the surge comes up rivers. 

**Sample answer for Choice C (New York, NY)**:

New York City is a at a higher risk of hurricanes in the future. As warmer ocean temperatures creep up the east coast of the US, hurricanes can remain strong and bring more severe impacts than before to the city. Also, more people continue to move to large cities on the coast, and with more people the risk is higher because the potential for damage is greater. 

The heavy precipitation has nowhere to go because the city is largely paved and impermeable. So that creates more flooding. And the water flows into the subways, which results in people being stranded since the trains shut down. The winds are worse because they're funneled through the urban canyons. 
","teacherTip":"","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

plugin.author_data:
{"tipType":"questionWrapper","questionWrapper":{"correctExplanation":"","distractorsExplanation":"","exemplar":"Answers will vary. 

They should plan to be prepared for storms that may be stronger with higher storm surge, higher winds, and/or more rainfall. Cities should be prepared with better sea walls, storm water drainage, evacuation plans, and better zoning. Increased wetlands, less development in high risk areas, and a more knowledgeable public can all help in lowering long term hurricane risk.

On a personal level, everyone should have a supply of water and non-perishable foods, as well as batteries and flashlights. An emergency radio would also be a good idea so that people can listen to news reports and know which areas they should not travel to. 
","teacherTip":"","teacherTipImageOverlay":"","location":"bottom"}}

plugin.author_data:
{"tipType":"windowShade","windowShade":{"windowShadeType":"discussionPoints","layout":"mediaLeft","initialOpenState":true,"content":"Now that all the activities are done, have the students complete the summary table. Have them look across activities, identify patterns, and think about how these patterns can be brought together to create an explanation for the guiding question: **How will hurricane risks and impacts change over the next 100 years?** 

See the Teacher Tip tab on this page regarding creation of a **Gotta Have** list. You may want to complete this activity before having the students write a final explanation. 

This is the place to talk about risks and impacts in the future. Questions include:
* What are some changes we are seeing in the near term (more intense hurricanes, more severe hazards) and are they being caused by climate change?
* What effect will another degree increase in air temperature or ocean temperature have on the risks and impacts of hurricanes?
* What are the uncertainties involved in making predictions about the severity of future risks and impacts?
","content2":"","mediaType":"none","mediaCaption":"Last, First. "Title of Work." Year created. Site Title [OR] Publisher. Gallery [OR] Location. http://www.url.com.","mediaURL":""}}
